# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objs as go

#Ignore warnings
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All"

source.236801b8:
# categorical features with missing values
categorical_nan = [feature for feature in df.columns if df[feature].isna().sum()>0 and df[feature].dtypes=='O']
print(categorical_nan)
source.1eb4abc9:
#Code by Larxel https://www.kaggle.com/andrewmvd/cyberbullying-classification-getting-started

fig = px.box(df,
             y = 'period',
             x = 'tribe',
             color = 'location',
             color_discrete_sequence = px.colors.diverging.curl,
             template = 'plotly_dark',
             title = 'Boxplot of Tribes per Location and Period'
)


fig.show()
source.ba9dd8db:
#Code by Larxel https://www.kaggle.com/andrewmvd/cyberbullying-classification-getting-started

fig = px.box(mexico,
             x = 'Name',
             y = 'tribe',
             color = 'period',
             color_discrete_sequence = px.colors.diverging.curl,
             template = 'plotly_dark',
             title = 'Boxplot of Mexico Tribes'
)


fig.update_yaxes(range = [0,80])
fig.show()

source.ead06f90:
##Code by Taha07  https://www.kaggle.com/taha07/data-scientists-jobs-analysis-visualization/notebook

from wordcloud import WordCloud
from wordcloud import STOPWORDS
stopwords = set(STOPWORDS)
wordcloud = WordCloud(background_color = 'red',
                      colormap='PuBu_r',
                      height =2000,
                      width = 2000
                     ).generate(str(df["tribe"]))
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (12,12)
plt.axis("off")
plt.imshow(wordcloud)
plt.title("Indigenous Tribes")
plt.show()
source.8d3fc56e:
##Code by Taha07  https://www.kaggle.com/taha07/data-scientists-jobs-analysis-visualization/notebook

from wordcloud import WordCloud
from wordcloud import STOPWORDS
stopwords = set(STOPWORDS)
wordcloud = WordCloud(background_color = 'green',
                      colormap='PuBu_r',
                      height =2000,
                      width = 2000
                     ).generate(str(df["Name"]))
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (12,12)
plt.axis("off")
plt.imshow(wordcloud)
plt.title("Indigenous Names")
plt.show()
source.c508b617:
#Code by Varshini PJ  user: varshinipj

fig = px.scatter_mapbox(df,
# Here, plotly gets, (x,y) coordinates
lat="LAT",
lon="LON",
text='location',

                #Here, plotly detects color of series
                #size="available_capacity_dose1",
                color = "tribe",
                labels="location",

                zoom=8,
                center={"lat":43.087000, "lon":-96.152700},
                height=600,
                width=800)
fig.update_layout(mapbox_style='stamen-terrain')
fig.update_layout(margin={"r": 0, "t": 0, "l": 0, "b": 0})
fig.update_layout(title_text="North Dakota Tribe Location")
fig.show()
